name: CommonWealth Beacon
title: Amid severe weather, Massachusetts must invest in protecting nature for all
authors: David O'Neill, Kris Sarri, Katie Theoharides and Jodi Valenta
description: Trees, parks, and green spaces are not just nice to have—they are critical, low-cost infrastructure that provide nature-based solutions to bolster climate resilience.
text:
MASSACHUSETTS IS IN a new era of severe weather and damaging storms. Flash floods in Leominster and the Berkshires, extreme heat in Boston, rising sea levels along the coast, and prolonged droughts are no longer rare events—they are our new reality. And their impacts are not felt equally. To protect all Massachusetts residents from these impacts of climate change — regardless of ZIP code— we must do more as a state to protect our rivers, lakes, forests, farms, and other natural areas.
That is why the Nature for Massachusetts Coalition, representing more than 95 conservation, environmental justice, and community organizations, along with members of the outdoor industry, are urging the Legislature to pass the Nature for All bill (H 901/S 2571) this session.
The Nature for All bill, which would dedicate funds from the existing state sales tax on sporting goods to raise $100 million every year for protecting and conserving water and nature, is our coalition’s top priority. While a parallel ballot initiative reflects growing public support, the fastest and most effective path forward is legislative action. The bill is the perfect complement to the climate resiliency investments proposed by the Healey administration in their MassReady Act. We urge lawmakers: don’t wait.
Trees, parks, and green spaces are not just nice to have—they are critical, low-cost infrastructure that provide nature-based solutions to bolster climate resilience. They cool our cities, absorb stormwater, and improve public health and access to safe drinking water. But access is unequal, and without a coordinated approach, the gap will only grow.  
The Nature for All bill would help level the playing field by identifying communities most in need of green space and climate resilience and supporting them with state funding to protect and restore that green space. It would enable smart investments in parks, greenways, and nature-based solutions all across the state, with community input at the center.
Climate resiliency isn’t the only issue this legislation addresses. It also will improve access to parks and green space. More than 1.5 million people in Massachusetts—including 300,000 children—lack access to a park or natural area within a 10-minute walk of home. These are often the same neighborhoods facing the worst effects of severe weather: heat islands, flood risk, and polluted runoff.
We’ve already seen efforts to change this work in practice.
In Boston, Trust for Public Land, Boston Parks and Recreation Department, and Boston Public Schools partnered with students at the Chittick Elementary School in Hyde Park and residents of the surrounding community to redesign a deteriorating and flood-prone schoolyard. Using green infrastructure and nature-based solutions, it was transformed into a renovated, safe, climate-resilient schoolyard and public park that mitigates the heat island effect and manages stormwater runoff, while closing a gap in park access for surrounding neighborhoods.
In Chelsea, GreenRoots, The Neighborhood Developers, and Mass Audubon are working together to acquire 18 acres of waterfront property and transform it into a broadly accessible, climate-resilient park, mixed-income housing, and community amenities along the Chelsea Creek waterfront. 
The Nature Conservancy is helping coastal communities adapt to climate change. With Massachusetts ranking third nationally in affordable housing at risk from coastal flooding, every dollar spent on climate resilience counts and can reduce future damages, protect people, and cut carbon emissions.
North of Boston, The Trustees is restoring thousands of acres of salt marsh in the Great Marsh, along the coast in Essex County. Along with numerous partners, The Trustees is remediating the marshland to help it adapt to sea level rise and bolster its ability to store carbon. This will help reduce storm surge and flood risk to uplands while also enhancing habitat for several wildlife species that rely on the marsh, including the saltmarsh sparrow.
The Nature for All bill builds upon these successes—and brings statewide coordination, resources, and urgency to address these dire needs.
The climate crisis demands more than reactive measures—it calls for bold action. That is why state Sen. Paul Feeney and state Reps. Natalie Blais and Samantha Montaño are leading the sponsorship of the bill, joined by bipartisan support from 52 members of the Legislature.
Managing the impacts of climate change is interconnected with the Commonwealth’s goals for health care, housing, food security, climate change, and land and water conservation. These efforts should be integrated and aligned to avoid conflicts and enable progress. Passing the Nature for All bill now will reduce harm from extreme heat and flooding; improve health and quality of life, create more resilient communities, and ensure every resident—no matter their ZIP code—has access to the joy and benefits of nature.
Massachusetts has been an environmental leader before. We built the nation’s first public park, and our forests, beaches, and parks are part of what makes Massachusetts a great place to live.
The cost of inaction is increasing. Let’s lead again—by investing in nature and protecting those most at risk from extreme weather. 
David O’Neill is president and CEO of Mass Audubon. Kris Sarri is state director of  The Nature Conservancy in Massachusetts. Katie Theoharides is president and CEO of The Trustees. Jodi Valenta is associate vice president and Massachusetts state director of Trust for Public Land.

name: California
title: For families like mine, the Eaton Fire disaster didn’t arrive on neutral ground
description: Property loss in Black and Brown communities hasn't been accidental. It comes from redlining, racial covenants, gentrification, discriminatory lending, insurance practices and now disaster recovery practices.
text:
Guest Commentary written by

Zella Knight
Zella Knight is a fire survivor and community advocate from Altadena


By the time my parents made a home in Altadena, they had already survived the Jim Crow South.  They had carried with them an understanding that for Black families, safety, property and opportunity are never guaranteed.
Homeownership for them was not simply a personal achievement; it was an act of repair.  It was a way of claiming dignity in a country that had long denied Black families the right to build, keep and pass down stability.
Our home stood for decades. It held birthdays and celebrations of life, holidays and ordinary moments of care. It was a gathering place for family and neighbors, a refuge from a world that still too often devalues Black and Brown Life.  It was meant to be an inheritance — a rare form of generational wealth in a nation where Black families have been systematically excluded from wealth-building opportunities.
Then came the Eaton fire. In a single catastrophic event, the house was destroyed.  
The most devastating loss was not material. My younger brother, who lived there, through displacement was traumatized and later died. His life and the future my parents worked to secure for him and his siblings was taken from us.
Disasters are often described as equalizers.  Fires, floods and wind do not discriminate.  But that framing ignores history.  It ignores how racial injustice shapes vulnerability, loss and recovery long before disaster strikes.  
For Black and Brown families, catastrophe does not arrive on neutral ground.
Property loss in Black and Brown communities has never been accidental. From redlining and racial covenants, gentrification and discriminatory lending, insurance practices and disaster recovery systems — Black homeownership has been consistently undermined.
When a fire destroys a Black family’s home, it compounds generations of dispossession. What is lost is not only a structure, but equity built over decades in a system that never made it easy.  What disappears are irreplaceable records of survival, photographs, documents, heirlooms and too often lives.
The weight of earlier losses
Grief in Black families is rarely singular. It accumulates. It carries the weight of earlier losses that were never fully mourned because survival required moving forward.
The fire reopened wounds my parents carried from the South — the persistent knowledge that even when you do everything “right” safety can still be taken.  
This is why intergenerational healing is not an abstract or academic concept. For families like mine, it is a necessity. Healing begins with truthtelling — naming how racism magnifies disaster, how Black families are more likely to be underinsured, displaced for longer periods and offered fewer recovery resources. It also requires refusing to privatize grief when systemic failures are involved.
My parents believed deeply in community because community was how they survived Jim Crow.  That belief carried us through the aftermath of the fire. 
Neighbors, friends, acquaintances, strangers showed up not just with condolences, but with care. That relational support is a form of wealth rarely acknowledged in policy discussions, yet it is often the difference between despair and survival. 
Still, community resilience cannot substitute for institutional responsibility.
If racial justice is to mean more than rhetoric, it must address what disasters reveal. Why are Black families more likely to lose generational wealth in catastrophes?  Why is recovery slower and more bureaucratic for communities shaped by historic disinvestment? Why are families expected to be endlessly “resilient” without repair?
Intergenerational healing requires policy responses that acknowledge history. It requires equitable disaster aid, fair insurance practices, protections for inherited property, culturally competent mental health services and reimagining programs so they don’t displace families from communities they helped build. 
The Eaton Fire took a home. Displacement took a life and shattered dreams. But these did not erase the legacy my parents built — a commitment to dignity, community and truth. 
Intergenerational healing is not forgetting what was taken. It is about refusing to allow that loss to be normalized.
If we want a future where Black and Brown families can truly build and pass down stability, racial justice must extend to how we prepare for, respond to and recover from catastrophe. Anything less ensures that fires like ours will continue to burn through generations.

name: California
title: Candidate commentary: California’s insurance crisis is pervasive but fixable
description: Insurers in California pulled back coverage or left the state after years of over-regulation, price controls and poor wildfire prevention.
text:
Guest Commentary written by

Stacy Korsgaden
Stacy Korsgaden, who is running for Insurance Commissioner,  owns an  insurance and financial services agency.


With the first anniversary of the devastating Southern California wildfires approaching, CalMatters asked candidates for the 2026 state Insurance Commissioner race to share thoughts on what the state can do to help victims and stabilize insurers. This is the third response. Read the other candidate responses here and here.
California is facing an insurance crisis that threatens the financial security of families, homeowners, and small businesses across the state. 
Coverage is becoming harder to obtain, premiums are rising, and policy cancellations are increasing. These developments are understandably alarming. But the good news: There is hope.
I have been a licensed insurance professional since 1988, and with close to 40 years of experience I can tell you, insurance is not merely a financial product, it is a promise. It is a cornerstone of economic stability that allows families to recover from tragedy and businesses to survive unforeseen loss. That system has served California well for generations. It can do so again.
Throughout my career as an insurance agent and business owner, my work began long before a claim was ever filed. The most important service we provided was preparation, making sure clients were properly protected before disaster struck. When the unthinkable did occur, being present to guide them through recovery was both a responsibility and a privilege. That is the role insurance is meant to play in society.
So how did we arrive at a moment where insurers are pulling back, denying coverage, or leaving entire markets? The answer is not sudden greed or indifference. It is the result of decades of accumulating regulations, rigid price controls, insufficient wildfire prevention and mitigation, and other unmanaged risk factors that have steadily eroded the system’s stability.
Insurance is fundamentally about pricing risk accurately. When that process is constrained, insurers cannot reliably operate. The result is exactly what Californians are experiencing now: reduced availability, deteriorating service, fewer choices for consumers and escalating prices.
Customers are angry and confused. Agents are left without options for their clients. Insurers face mounting losses. Meanwhile, political finger pointing has replaced serious discussion, and trust in the system continues to erode.
California does not need to choose between consumer protection and a functioning insurance market. We can have both. Achieving that balance requires a recommitment to basic principles: Free markets, actuarial soundness, California managing wildfire risks and allowing private sector innovations.
Insurance thrives on predictability and trust. When those elements are restored, capital returns, coverage expands and our working families benefit from greater choice and better service.
When a functioning free market is restored in California, capital will return and support the growth of insurers willing to serve the state. Renewed competition will naturally reduce dependence on the FAIR Plan and allow for its depopulation.
The FAIR Plan was never intended to insure the many. It was designed as a last resort option for a limited number of high risk properties. Its long-term stability depends on removing the excess burden created by the absence of a competitive private market.
As insurers are once again able to grow and write policies in California, coverage will shift back where it belongs, into the private market, restoring balance and choice for our community.
The insurance industry has long been a quiet but essential pillar of our economy. With truth, discipline, and hard work it can be again. This crisis is fixable. 
The candidate guest commentaries are being published in the order in which they were received.

name: South Carolina Daily Gazette
title: SC State University flag to fly from Statehouse during King Day at the Dome
description: COLUMBIA — This year’s annual King Day at the Dome will feature a first: The flag of South Carolina’s only public historically Black university will fly atop the Statehouse as people gather below to honor Martin Luther King Jr. The main speaker from the Statehouse steps Jan. 19 will be New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker. […]
text:
The flag of South Carolina State University will fly on the Statehouse dome below the state flag on Monday, Jan. 19, 2026, to celebrate the Bulldogs winning a national football championship. (Photo by Travis Bell/STATEHOUSE CAROLINA/Special to the SC Daily Gazette)COLUMBIA — This year’s annual King Day at the Dome will feature a first: The flag of South Carolina’s only public historically Black university will fly atop the Statehouse as people gather below to honor Martin Luther King Jr.
The main speaker from the Statehouse steps Jan. 19 will be New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker. Others include California Rep. Ro Khanna and Democratic National Committee Chair Jaime Harrison of Columbia, who delivered last year’s keynote speech, according to the NAACP’s state chapter, which organizes the annual event.
Above them, from sunrise to sunset, the flag of South Carolina State University will fly just under the U.S. and state flags. The unfurling officially celebrates the Bulldogs’ 40-38 fourth-overtime victory at last month’s Celebration Bowl, which made them national football champions for historically Black colleges and universities.
The flag-flying honor is definitely a first for South Carolina State, according to the college. It’s believed to be the first time any HBCU flag has flown from the dome.
The timing on MLK Day magnifies the meaning: 26 years ago, the NAACP organized the first King Day at the Dome to protest the Confederate flag flying in the same spot.
Rep. Hamiton Grant called the recognition of his alma mater, by order of GOP Gov. Henry McMaster, a symbol of unity across political differences.
“I think that should send a message to the people of South Carolina that we tend to agree more than we disagree,” the Columbia Democrat told the SC Daily Gazette. “Our history as a school, our history as a people and what we mean to the state, is something everyone should be proud of.”
Grant said college officials requested the Jan. 19 date.
He and Sen. Deon Tedder, also a South Carolina State graduate, will jointly present the flag to the Bulldogs football team in Orangeburg during its celebratory parade days later, Tedder wrote in his Dec. 19 letter to McMaster.

SC State flag request 
“It will be my honor,” McMaster wrote back about having the flag flown on MLK Day.
South Carolina State’s Dec. 13 victory in Atlanta over Prairie View A&M marked the Bulldogs’ second national HBCU championship title and third appearance at the Celebration Bowl in five years. They beat Jackson State 31-10 in 2021 to take the title.
It’s become tradition for a college flag to fly on the dome following a national championship. But lawmakers didn’t make a flag request following the Bulldogs’ 2021 win, Grant said.
Last month’s win, which avenged the Bulldogs’ 28-7 loss to Jackson State a year earlier, was dubbed by HBCU Gameday “one of the most dramatic finishes in HBCU football history.”
“This championship represents more than an athletic triumph; it is a moment of pride for the entire state of South Carolina,” Tedder, D-North Charleston, wrote Dec. 15 in his initial letter to McMaster that didn’t seek a specific date for the flag’s flying. “It celebrates the dedication of student-athletes, coaches, alumni, and supporters whose collective efforts embody excellence, resilience, and unity.”
King Day speakers
This year’s theme for King Day at the Dome is “The Time is Now.”
The event starts at 8 a.m. at Zion Baptist Church on Washington Street. Around 10 a.m., participants will walk the half-mile to the Statehouse for speeches.
Unlike in 2024, when then-Vice President Kamala Harris was the main speaker, there won’t be any metal detectors that people have to walk through. The extra layers of security for her attendance created a bottleneck for the crowd to get from Main Street to the Statehouse lawn.
The event celebrating King’s legacy has become a must-attend event for Democratic presidential candidates courting the support of Black voters in this early primary state.
In 2020, Joe Biden was among eight White House hopefuls marching arm in arm from the church to the Statehouse. They did not include Booker, who was instead at his Columbia campaign office thanking staff after dropping out of the race a week earlier.
This year, Booker will give the keynote address. Last spring, he broke the record for talking the longest on the U.S. Senate floor. His speech, at more than 25 hours, surpassed the 24-hour record set in 1957 by South Carolina Sen. Strom Thurmond, then a Democrat, as he filibustered civil rights legislation.
But Booker’s selection is not a sign of any future endorsement, should he decide to run again in 2028.
He’s giving the speech because he was the first person to reach out and ask, said Brenda Murphy, the state NAACP president.
Khanna, who represents a California district in the San Francisco Bay known as Silicon Valley, will also speak. Last July, he was in South Carolina for a four-day swing to rally opposition to the Trump administration. In Goose Creek, his “Benefits Over Billionaires” town hall instead showed Democrats’ frustrations with their own party, The Post and Courier reported.
It’s been over a decade since a Confederate flag flew over the event.
The flag came off the dome six months after the inaugural King Day at the Dome. The 2000 legislative compromise that took it down made both MLK Day and Confederate Memorial Day state holidays. It also put a smaller, square version of the battle flag on a 30-foot pole beside the Confederate monument on the Statehouse’s front lawn. Its prominent place along Columbia’s main thoroughfare made the flag more visible than it had been before.
The NAACP continued to call for the flag’s total removal from Statehouse grounds, and speakers pointed to the flag during the annual event.
But lawmakers refused to revisit the issue until 2015, after an avowed white supremacist gunned down nine people at Charleston’s historic Emanual African Methodist Episcopal Church, known as Mother Emanuel. Less than a month after the shooting, the flag and the pole it flew on were taken down. The law passed by the Legislature to do so sent the flag to a state museum.

name: California
title: Gavin Newsom touts billions in new revenue but skips his own budget release
description: The governor made rosy projections and dropped big revenue numbers in his speech Thursday. Here’s what he said, and didn’t say, about California’s fiscal future.
text:
In summary
The governor made rosy projections and dropped big revenue numbers in his speech Thursday. Here’s what he said, and didn’t say, about California’s fiscal future.


Gov. Gavin Newsom painted a rosy picture of California’s fiscal future during his State of the State address Thursday. Flashing top-line numbers, the Democratic governor touted billions of  dollars more in revenue, proposed new investments in education and pledged more toward the state’s reserves and pension debt.
But that was a one-sided story. 
It’s not clear whether Newsom will forecast a budget deficit for the 2026-27 fiscal year, how big it will be and whether closing the gap would require painful spending cuts to core services like child care, food assistance and Medi-Cal, the state’s health care coverage for low-income residents, especially as federal funding diminishes. 
Yet Newsom will be absent from his last annual budget proposal presentation Friday, when details of his spending plan will be unveiled, leaving his Department of Finance Director Joe Stephenshaw and Chief Deputy Director of Budgets Erika Li to field those questions.
Newsom’s forecast will likely be far sunnier than the grim outlook by the nonpartisan Legislative Analyst’s Office, which in November projected an $18 billion deficit despite higher-than-expected tax revenue thanks to a booming AI industry. A shortfall of that size would require long-term fixes, although state leaders had relied on Band-Aids such as accounting maneuvers, internal borrowing and withdrawals from the state’s reserves to balance the books in past years.
But according to Newsom, California will have a $248.3 billion general fund next year — $13 billion higher  than his office predicted in June. 
Newsom also touted Thursday that the state would have $42.3 billion more in revenue than forecast last year. But that figure is for a three-year span, state Department of Finance spokesperson H.D. Palmer told CalMatters. 
The omission of the cumulative nature of the $42 billion makes Newsom’s speech “troubling,” said Sen. Roger Niello, a Roseville Republican and vice chair of the Senate Budget Committee.
“That would be an intentional misrepresentation of the fact,” he said.
Nonetheless, Newsom teased multiple new proposals with unknown price tags or timelines, such as fully funding the state’s universal transitional kindergarten program and providing universal before and after-school programs at elementary schools. He also proposed spending $1 billion to add high-need community schools and redirecting $1 billion in Proposition 1 mental health funds annually for housing and homelessness.
The governor briefly nodded to “long-term structural challenges,” proposing a $7.3 billion deposit to the reserve fund, roughly the amount the state withdrew last year, whichwould bring the rainy day fund balance to roughly $21 billion. He also proposed to spend $11.8 billion over the next few years to pay down the state’s pension debt, including $3 billion in next year’s budget. 
Some Democratic lawmakers struck a cautious tone while largely blaming President Donald Trump for withholding funds from Californians in need. 
“California will not be able to fill the holes that have been left by the federal government,” said newly elected Senate President Pro Tem Monique Limón, a Santa Barbara Democrat. “We have to go back and look (at) what is feasible.”
‘How big is the bubble?’Senate Budget Committee Chair John Laird, a Santa Cruz Democrat
Sen. John Laird, a Santa Cruz Democrat and the new chair of the Senate Budget Committee, warned that the high revenue projection indicates a bubble. Laird, who was elected to the state Assembly in 2002 after the 2000 dot-com bubble burst, said he’s concerned the AI-driven boom may not last. 
“I think everybody agrees that this level of revenue can’t be maintained, but how big is the bubble? That’s probably the question,” he told CalMatters.
The Legislature must start chipping away at the long-term structural deficit this year instead of punting the problem, he said.
“We’re gonna have to do a piece of it,” he said. “We can’t go into next year with a $30 or $37 billion shortfall, because the reserves amount doesn’t get anywhere near that.” 
Continued fight over homelessness funding
Newsom has tussled with counties over homelessness funding for years as political pressure to resolve the state’s homeless crisis continues to mount. Newsom has blamed counties for failing to deliver results despite his $24 billion investment over the years. Only a portion of the funding goes to county agencies and there is no dedicated annual funding to fight homelessness.
On Thursday, Newsom again bashed counties for the problem while attributing a drop in unsheltered homeless people last year to his statewide programs. In the same breath, he also proposed to redirect “$1 billion in annual mental health funding to housing and treatment for people living on the streets” under Proposition 1, a voter-approved bond primarily for mental health beds and supportive housing.
“No more excuses — it’s time to bring people off the streets, out of encampments, into housing, into treatment. Counties need to do their job!” Newsom said, drawing applause from legislators.
It wasn’t immediately clear how he plans to allocate those dollars. He did not mention any funding for the Homeless Housing, Assistance and Prevention program, the state’s main homelessness funding source. 
The California State Association of Counties, which represents all 58 counties and has lobbied for an annual allocation of $1 billion in HHAP funding, was displeased.
“Playing a shell game with existing funds is no substitute for the most successful program addressing homelessness at the local level,” said association CEO Graham Knaus. “Why on Earth would the state abdicate its responsibility and allow homelessness to soar again?”
Newsom’s plan also startled county behavioral health service providers, who rely on Prop. 1 dollars for services. 
“While these one-time bricks and mortar investments are promising, the $1 billion in funding for ongoing housing subsidies under Proposition 1 comes at the expense of redirected mental health treatment and prevention programs,” said Michelle Doty Cabrera, executive director of the County Behavioral Health Directors Association.
No mention of Medi-Cal
Newsom also gave next to no detail on the outlook for Medi-Cal — the state’s most expensive program with a $200 billion budget and therefore an attractive target for potential cuts. He didn’t even name the program in his speech.
The governor slammed Trump for passing a federal budget that could kick 1.8 million Californians off their insurance and raise the premiums for another 2 million. The state would have to spend at least $1.3 billion more than previously expected next year just to implement the federal law, the LAO previously estimated. 

Learn more about legislators mentioned in this story.


 Roger Niello
 Republican, State Senate, District 6 (Roseville)


 John Laird
 Democrat, State Senate, District 17 (Santa Cruz)


 Monique Limón
 Democrat, State Senate, District 19 (Santa Barbara)


 Mia Bonta
 Democrat, State Assembly, District 18 (Oakland)



Assemblymember Mia Bonta, an Oakland Democrat who chairs the Assembly Health Committee, said the state must “use the bully pulpit” to fight the federal government, find ways to lower costs or even revive indigent care, a form of last-resort care that has largely become obsolete due to Medi-Cal. 
“Because the alternative is, people are going to be dying on the streets,” Bonta said.
Bonta said the Legislature should explore new funding sources, such as a pair of proposed wealth tax ballot measures to fund health care and education that Newsom opposes. 
“We need to think about ways that we can increase our revenue sources … (with) openness around looking at our tax structure,” she said, adding that there are ways “to make sure that everybody’s carrying their fair share.”

name: Mississippi Today
title: Wrestler’s multimillion dollar ‘self-help curriculum’ helped crack open a wider welfare scandal
description: The Thad Cochran United States Courthouse in Jackson, Miss., Thursday, Jan. 8, 2026
text:
The audio version of this story is AI generated and is not human reviewed. It may contain errors or inaccuracies.
Much of the third day of the trial of former WWE wrestler Ted “Teddy” DiBiase Jr. consisted of testimony from the former welfare agency employee who drafted the first memos about the alleged scheme to misuse welfare money that was supposed to help needy Mississippians.
Mississippi Department of Human Services Inspector General David Barton’s colleagues in budgets and accounting had found a peculiar address on an invoice and brought it to Barton in 2019.  The retired Mississippi National Guard colonel took a closer look and quickly made some alarming discoveries. 
DiBiase had appeared to be an employee of the Mississippi Department of Human Services. He had an office on the executive floor and accompanied the agency director at the time, John Davis, to most meetings. Barton assumed DiBiase was being paid for his time, but he couldn’t find any payment from the agency to the wrestler.
Ted DiBiase Jr. speaks at the governor’s Healthy Teens Rally in 2018.
Starting with Barton’s tip, investigators eventually unraveled how the Mississippi Department of Human Services had pushed tens of millions of federal welfare dollars to two nonprofits through subgrants, which were then used by various people as a vehicle to skirt federal regulations. 
DiBiase received $3.1 million from the nonprofits, auditors found, with funding coming from the federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program and The Emergency Food Assistance Program. The federal government alleges this was embezzlement, while DiBiase asserts he was a lawful contractor.
Testimony Thursday from U.S. Department of Agriculture branch chief Polly Fairfield revealed that in 2018, the year DiBiase received nearly $500,000 from the emergency food program, the entire state of Mississippi received $1.2 million to administer the program. 
Fairfield explained that through the program, the federal government supplies food – fruits, vegetables, beans, meat, dairy, grains – to states, plus administrative money to pay for the storage and distribution of those goods to needy residents. 
DiBiase’s contract represents nearly half of the state’s entire administrative resources for the program that year. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Meynardie said the primary evidence of DiBiase’s work under that contract was a list of food pantries DiBiase compiled – “essentially a Google search.” 
This was all possible, Barton’s testimony demonstrated, because of a widespread breakdown of controls at the agency. Davis was appointed in 2016 by former Gov. Phil Bryant and was allowed to unilaterally choose who would receive subgrants and move money around with the ease of a text message. 
MORE TRIAL COVERAGE:DAY 2: Opening statements in welfare scandal trial paint former director as villain who doled out millions over infatuationDAY 1: 83 witnesses could enter the ring in Mississippi welfare scandal trialTRIAL PREVIEW: Ex-WWE wrestler faces feds in first – and potentially only – criminal trial in Mississippi welfare scandal
It’s not unusual for state welfare departments to send federal grant funds to nonprofits to provide services to satisfy the goals of a program. But Mississippi barely monitored these nonprofits, even failing to maintain a list of entities it had awarded funds, the auditor’s office claimed.
If a nonprofit subgrantee wanted to outsource some of the services it promised to provide, it wasn’t required to tell the welfare agency who it contracted with and for what. Barton said he and his colleagues revised the agency’s subgrant manual to change this during Davis’ departure in 2019.
Barton joined the Mississippi Department of Human Services in 2017 shortly after the launch of the internal audit division, a new department prompted by legislation. He said one of his first tasks was to gather and build a repository for past agency audits. 
The problems predated Davis becoming director: Barton said in 2015, the agency’s audit found a significant deficiency in how it monitored subgrants. In 2016, the finding worsened to noncompliance. This repeated in 2017 and 2018.
“Did you find it frustrating,” DiBiase’s defense lawyer Sidney Lampton asked Barton, “when there would be a corrective action plan from DHS about how they were going to fix or improve, and then the very next year, the audit would say, ‘Y’all did the very same thing you did last year.’”
Change would eventually come, but only after Barton’s memo.
In October of 2018, under Davis’ leadership, the agency created an Office of Inspector General, which Barton led. Prior to this, a tip like a mysterious address on an invoice would have gone to a different division that Barton said did not have the ability to do the kind of investigation he did.
Barton’s first June 2019 memo was not primarily about DiBiase, but his brother Brett DiBiase, who also worked for Davis. The brother, another former wrestler, had contracted with the welfare agency to provide addiction education courses to state employees, but on his invoices to the agency, he suspiciously listed his company’s address as Davis’ post office box. Investigators later found Brett DiBiase was in rehab in California during the time he was supposed to be performing the contract.
After this discovery, Davis was quickly pushed out of MDHS. Bryant called the departure a retirement and praised Davis as someone who “dedicated his life to serving others.”
Once this information reached the auditor’s office, Barton said an agent there asked him to continue compiling what he could about what Davis was doing with the wrestlers.
Former welfare agency director John Davis is set to plead guilty to federal and state charges related to his role in the welfare scandal. (AP Photo)
The second memo discussed Teddy DiBiase’s leadership training program called “Law of 16,” which the government described in its opening statement as a self-help curriculum “copied from a number of sources.” Barton described the presentations, sometimes elaborate events with linen tablecloths, table arrangements and a performance by a gospel choir, in his memo as an “interactive praise/preaching type environment.” 
Davis rewarded DHS employees who attended the wrestler’s talks with days off – which is not allowed under state rules, Barton said. One of these trainings consisted of attendees watching the action film “Marine 2” produced by WWE’s film division and starring DiBiase.
MDHS also purchased polo shirts and Patagonia jackets branded with the “Law of 16” logo.
Days before Barton’s tip led to Davis’ ouster, DiBiase accompanied the welfare director to testify about Mississippi’s safety-net model before Congress. Davis described “Law of 16” during his testimony as “our personal and professional development programs” he hoped to bring to welfare recipients “to make sure that they are empowered to be whom they have been called to be.”
Davis is scheduled to testify Friday.

name: Utah News Dispatch
title: ‘Hate is an opportunity to educate and unite,’ says latest Utah Democrat to launch bid for Congress
description: The response to Utah’s latest Democrat to jump into the crowded race for the state’s newly drawn 1st Congressional District was swift and widespread.  Liban Mohamed’s campaign announcement video posted to X on Monday has since gained more than 2.2 million views. But many of the online responses to the video on the social media […]
text:
Liban Mohamed (Photo by Abhiijith Harikumar, courtesy of the Liban for Congress campaign)The response to Utah’s latest Democrat to jump into the crowded race for the state’s newly drawn 1st Congressional District was swift and widespread. 
Liban Mohamed’s campaign announcement video posted to X on Monday has since gained more than 2.2 million views. But many of the online responses to the video on the social media platform drew condemnation from the leadership of the Utah Democratic Party. 
“We take no position on Democratic nominees for CD1,” the Utah Democratic Party said in a post about Mohamed’s campaign video. However, it added: “The flood of racist and religious hate directed at Liban Mohamed is disgusting. Let’s be clear where it’s coming from: the racism and white fragility on display from Republicans across this state is dangerous and embarrassing.” 

We take no position on Democratic nominees for CD1.
The flood of racist and religious hate directed at Liban Mohamed is disgusting. Let’s be clear where it’s coming from: the racism and white fragility on display from Republicans across this state is dangerous and embarrassing. https://t.co/b5KB6OSwTx
— Utah Democratic Party (@UtahDemocrats) January 6, 2026

Many of the online responses to the video called for Mohamed to be deported. But Mohamed is a U.S citizen. He was born in Logan and raised in Ogden. His parents are Somali immigrants, who he said came to Utah in the ’80s to attend Utah State University during a time when the civil war in Somalia broke out. While they continued their education, they decided to stay and raise their family in Utah. 
“Utah was a place that treated them so well. A place that educated them. A place that accepted them. So they settled down here, they had their kids. So I was born here,” Mohamed told Utah News Dispatch in an interview Thursday. 
Mohamed, 27, is Black and Muslim, and he currently lives in Salt Lake City. He decided to launch a bid for Congress after he said some leaders from the Black and Muslim communities encouraged him to run. He said he felt a “moral obligation to step up and try my best to fulfill that calling.” 
In the days since his campaign announcement, Mohamed said he’s been focused on the positive response both on and offline — from the “people from communities that are entirely different from myself flocking in my defense.” 
He said his phone has “blown up” with messages from people asking how they can volunteer and support his campaign, “that they feel like I can be that person that re-instills their hope.” 
“When I saw all of this, I teared up, honestly,” he said. “Because my dream of what I could be has already begun to unfold (from) a single post. So I hope that I can live up to those expectations and be that person the community is yearning for.” 
Mohamed said he’s intent on focusing on real-world issues — like bringing down costs for housing, child care and health care — rather than the online vitriol.
“Hate is an opportunity to educate and unite, and we will find beauty behind the madness,” he said. “I think this virality is an example of our ability to galvanize the community.” 
Mohamed said he hopes the focus isn’t on the “horrible rhetoric I was facing, but the beautiful defense that thousands came behind me with.” 










Hate is an opportunity to educate and unite, and we will find beauty behind the madness.


– Liban Mohamed


Mohamed joins at least five other Democrats who have announced bids for Utah’s new 1st Congressional District, which under a court-ordered map is concentrated around the northern part of Salt Lake City, and is projected to lean heavily Democratic. 
Other declared Democratic candidates include Salt Lake City Council member Eva Lopez Chavez, state Sen. Kathleen Riebe, state Sen. Nate Blouin, former state Sen. Derek Kitchen, and Utah’s last Democratic congressman, former Rep. Ben McAdams. 
Most recently, Mohamed worked on TikTok’s public policy team, managing the company’s response to political investigations — a role he said he has resigned from in order to run for Congress. He also previously worked for Meta, where he focused on data center sustainability policies, and as a government relations director at the American Heart Association in Utah. 
He said he hopes to take his expertise in tech — and his perspective as a young American — to Congress to represent younger generations and act as “somebody who can work across the aisle while simultaneously holding true to their progressive values and their principles.” 
While many of the responses to his campaign announcement were “vile and instilled fear into our communities,” Mohamed said he also understands that people who use bigoted or racist rhetoric around immigration issues are often scared or frustrated with the same economic problems he wants to help tackle. 
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Anger and blame placed on immigrants, Mohamed said, “are coming from a place of struggle. There is a reality behind those frustrations, and that reality is what I want to fight for, which is making our community a community that has economic stability.” 
“We’re going to make this campaign a campaign about positivity, a campaign about policy, and fighting for the frustrations that are at the root of all of these different concerns, which are people’s pocketbooks,” he said. 
“But the pocketbooks are not being hurt because of immigrants or minorities,” Mohamed added. “Their pocketbooks are being hurt because they’re being exploited by the wealthy. They’re being paid low wages, because affording a roof over your head is becoming increasingly difficult. Because they’re one hospital trip away from bankruptcy. Because raising a family is harder than ever.” 
So, Mohamed said he’s going to “focus on the real fundamental issues that I believe are the underlying motive behind these frustrations, and not focus on the bigotry and all of the rhetoric that is nothing but a distraction.” 
Mohamed’s campaign announcement also came at a time when President Donald Trump has taken aim at Somali immigrants. Immigration enforcement agents increased their presence in Minnesota in recent weeks as part of a targeted campaign ordered by Trump to deport undocumented Somali immigrants.  
Report: ICE headed to Twin Cities targeting Somali immigrants

Additionally, earlier this month the Trump administration said states would need to provide “justification” proving that federal child care funds are being spent on “legitimate” entities. The comments followed fraud allegations in Minnesota related to the state’s child care programs, which were already being investigated by state and federal agencies but blew up following a YouTube video by a right-wing social media influencer. The allegations particularly targeted child care centers run by Somali citizens of the state.
Mohamed called the intersection of his campaign announcement and Trump’s rhetoric surrounding Somali immigrants a “matter of coincidence.” He said he decided to enter the race before Trump’s comments against Somali immigrants began ramping up.
While Mohamed said one part of the root of frustrations against immigrants can be traced to resource scarcity — leading people to think they have to “push out” immigrants — he said another part of the problem is the “permissive structure that Donald Trump and the MAGA movement has provided for people to feel so emboldened to openly be so vile.” 
“So I hope that the 2026 and 2028 (election) cycles put the cap on that permission structure so that people know that they have to be careful with their words and respect and love your neighbors,” he said.

name: Alabama Reflector
title: Alabama senator continues to delay legal contracts over Internet sales tax lawsuit
description: An Alabama legislator Thursday extended a delay of state agencies’ legal services contracts in protest of a lawsuit filed by several cities seeking changes to distributions of the state’s Internet sales tax. Sen. Greg Albritton, R-Atmore, held six legal contracts totaling more than $1 million at Thursday’s Contract Review Committee meeting as the lawsuit aga[...]
text:
Sen. Greg Albritton, R-Atmore (top) speaks to Sen. Lance Bell, R-Pell City in the Alabama Senate on May 6, 2024 at the Alabama Statehouse in Montgomery, Alabama.  Albritton has held legal services contracts for a second straight month over a lawsuit regarding the simplified sellers use tax. (Brian Lyman/Alabama Reflector)An Alabama legislator Thursday extended a delay of state agencies’ legal services contracts in protest of a lawsuit filed by several cities seeking changes to distributions of the state’s Internet sales tax.
Sen. Greg Albritton, R-Atmore, held six legal contracts totaling more than $1 million at Thursday’s Contract Review Committee meeting as the lawsuit against the levy, known as the Simplified Sellers Use Tax (SSUT), works its way through the court.
“We are now stuck and waiting to figure out what lawyers are going to come in and make a comment or try to deal with how the Legislature should handle public funds, who it should be going to and how it should be distributed,” Albritton said at the meeting. “That is the Legislature’s job. That is our constitutional responsibility. It has no role in the judicial matter at all.”
The move by Albritton, who also blocked the contracts at December’s Contract Review Committee, drew strong criticism from Rep. Chris England, D-Tuscaloosa, who defended the actions of the plaintiffs in the lawsuit. The city of Tuscaloosa, parts of which are in England’s district, is part of the lawsuit.
“The distribution of funds from the SSUT creates a unique issue for municipalities and counties across the state,” England said. “As more people buy things online, it reduces the amount that you take in from brick-and-mortar sales, which, by the way, they get more from brick-and-mortar sales than from online sales.”
The dispute came a few hours after the Association of County Commissions of Alabama (ACCA), which opposes the lawsuit, said that county law enforcement agencies could lose millions of dollars in funding should the cities prevail.
“County governments will spend almost $1 billion in providing funding to protect the citizens through the provision of law enforcement services in our state, almost a billion dollars,” said Sonny Brasfield, executive director of the ACCA, at a press conference in Montgomery Thursday. “During this current budget year, counties will receive about $200 million from SSUT, that money is essential in our ability to continue to provide the revenue that is necessary to protect our citizens.”
Before the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision in South Dakota v. Wayfair in 2018, local taxing authorities such as cities and counties could only collect revenues from sales taxes on businesses located within their respective boundaries. The Wayfair decision allowed taxing jurisdictions to collect taxes on sales through the Internet.
Cities filed a lawsuit in August to challenge the simplified sellers use tax, alleging that it violates Alabama’s constitution and that some of the retailers that the Alabama Department of Revenue approved of should be disqualified and instead pay the traditional local sales tax of 10%, not the reduced 8% they currently pay.
The plaintiffs in the lawsuit want the Alabama Department of Revenue to remove several companies from the program that they believe are ineligible for SSUT because they have a significant presence in the state.
Lawmakers modified the program to place more stringent eligibility requirements for retailers to qualify for the reduced tax rate in SSUT, but the city of Tuscaloosa stated in its lawsuit that it is forfeiting $14.6 million in tax revenues because of the differences in the tax rate that businesses are eligible for because of SSUT.
England said during the meeting that local schools lose money because sales taxes from the growing volume of online purchases are distributed differently than the sales taxes obtained through brick-and-mortar transactions. England also accused the Alabama Department of Revenue, the agency responsible for overseeing SSUT, of allowing some retailers to collect taxes from transactions through SSUT that are local and should be part of the traditional sales taxes which can be allocated directly to local schools.
“Apparently, the Department of Revenue decided that any online transaction, even the ones that were not intended to be, like for example, if you order something from Walmart that is delivered to your house and you bought it from there, that is not a simplified sellers use transaction,” England said.
A spokesperson for the Alabama Department of Revenue declined comment on Thursday, saying the department does not comment on pending litigation.
Albritton said that smaller, rural areas are subsidizing more urban centers because customers will purchase items in stores located in places such as Mobile because they live in Chatom, for example, that has few retailers. SSUT, he argued, helps balance out the revenue.
Law enforcement
Each county allocates a different amount of its share of SSUT money to law enforcement and it is not clear how much of it goes to law enforcement. But all counties set aside a significant amount to public safety, according to Brasfield.
“In about 55 of the 67 counties, law enforcement is at least half of the counties’ budget,” Brasfield said. “That means the money is going to law enforcement everywhere. In rural Alabama, a much higher percentage of the money is going to law enforcement than in other counties.”
Doug Singleton, chair of the Montgomery County Commission, and Montgomery County Sheriff Derrick Cunningham also attended the news conference to punctuate the point.
“It is about 12 to 15 deputies,” Singleton said about the impact of the lawsuit on law enforcement for Montgomery County.
The Association of the County Commissions of Alabama had been warning counties of the potential implications of the lawsuit throughout the year. The case is currently in mediation.
A message was sent to the city of Montgomery and the Alabama Education Association, the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, on Thursday.
City of Tuscaloosa Mayor Walt Maddox said in a statement on Thursday that, “The people of Alabama are entitled to a system that is legal and fair, and one that ensures local sales taxes generated in a community remain in that community to support schools, public safety, and overall quality of life.”
He also said that, “Today, millions of Alabamians are experiencing fewer teachers, fewer police officers, fewer firefighters, fewer road projects, and less economic development as a direct result of SSUT’s legal flaws.”
Steve Boone, city manager for the city of Mountain Brook, said that the current way that the Simplified Sellers Use Tax is structured to reduce the tax collections that urban centers such as his city could collect.
“If larger, urban areas are not collecting what they would otherwise get, then that means somebody else is receiving more than what they would normally get,” Boone said in an interview on Thursday.
Boone said Mountain Brook also uses revenue received by the city from the Simplified Sellers Use Tax to fund law enforcement. The money is part of the general fund for Mountain Brook, which is then allocated to various departments, including law enforcement.
Boone also said that the city recently increased its sales tax by 1% because of shortfalls in the budget.
“If we were collecting what we should be collecting from the SSUT … it could have avoided, perhaps, some percentage of our sales tax increase that we needed,” Boone said. “Our costs go up every year. And that is a constant struggle for all cities.”

name: Nevada Current
title: Clark County land trust program aims to provide housing families can afford
description: The prospect of purchasing a brand new 2,000-square-foot single-family home in the northwest part of the Las Vegas Valley for around $300,000 would be scoffed at by local realtors. But the opportunity to do just that is coming later this year, thanks to a new program spearheaded by Clark County. Last month, the county broke […]
text:
Clark County Commissioner Marilyn Kirkpatrick at the December groundbreaking for Rebecca Place, the county's first community land trust housing development. (Clark County video screengrab)The prospect of purchasing a brand new 2,000-square-foot single-family home in the northwest part of the Las Vegas Valley for around $300,000 would be scoffed at by local realtors. But the opportunity to do just that is coming later this year, thanks to a new program spearheaded by Clark County.
Last month, the county broke ground on a 30-home development dubbed Rebecca Place, located on Rebecca Road and Tropical Parkway, just outside of Centennial Hills in the northwest part of the Las Vegas metro area .
The 30 homes will be sold to local, first-time homebuyers earning between 80% and 100% of area median income. That currently equates to between $68,000 and $85,000 per year for a family of three.
So, what’s the catch?
Rebecca Place is part of a county-managed community land trust (CLT) designed to keep homes attainably priced in perpetuity.
It works like this: The homebuyer acquires a mortgage for the physical home but enters into a long-term renewable ground lease with the CLT. Removing the land from the equation keeps the sale price lower for the buyer, but it comes with a commitment that, when they eventually sell, the home will again be sold at a below-market rate, using the same formula used for the initial sale.
CLTs and other shared-equity models of homeownership aren’t new, but they are more often managed by a nonprofit rather than a public entity.
Clark County Commissioner Marilyn Kirkpatrick believes it’s the first community land trust managed by a local government in the Western United States, if not the country.
“We looked across the country,” she said. “There’s a lot of private land trusts, but there really wasn’t any local governments.”
Kirkpatrick, a former state legislator, said the Nevada State Legislature has previously pondered investing in land trusts but nothing has come of it, so the county decided it could be a leader on the issue.
According to the Las Vegas Realtors, the median sale price for existing single-family homes in Southern Nevada in November was $488,995. The median price for condos and townhomes was $303,750.
A rendering of a Rebecca Place home at the development site. (Clark County video screengrab)
The Rebecca Place homes — there are a few model types available — will be priced using a formula that takes into account the buyers’ incomes and expected to be in the low $300,000s.
“That is what many of the homes in that neighborhood sold for six, seven years ago,” said Kirkpatrick.
The homes are designed to fit into the surrounding neighborhood, so they have similar sized lots (most over 8,000 square feet), between 1,900 to 2,100 square feet of living space, and three-car garages.
All of those choices were intentional, says Kirkpatrick. The average home in the area has four or five cars. They are meant for families to grow and age in.
“We really took a lot of kid-gloves looking at it,” she added. “What made sense for the neighborhood? What makes sense for a future homebuyer? And really, for me, I’d personally just like it to be someone’s forever home. I hope they move in and never want to move out.”
According to Kirkpatrick, 800 people have already joined a waiting list to be notified about the Rebecca Place homes.
“Honestly, we haven’t really even advertised it yet,” she added. “So, that was all done through word of mouth…”
Prospective buyers, who will be subject to credit requirements, will eventually be entered into a lottery later this year.
In the meantime, the county is holding orientations to answer questions and emphasize how CLTs work.
Kirkpatrick stressed that people need to understand that shared-equity housing is vastly different from the unfettered, private real estate market. It is not designed for flippers, landlords or others who want to cash in the valley’s history of rising home prices.
“It’s intended to be attainable housing for the long term,” she said. “It’s intended to give (homeowners) a modest equity amount they can take and use for their next home for downpayment assistance. But it’s not, and should never be, intended to be a windfall for anybody.”
Kirkpatrick said the goal is for families to be moving into Rebecca Place by the last quarter of 2026.
She hopes between now and then the county can also break ground on other CLT developments, including one 200-unit development in the southwest that’s already been approved and is “moving through the process.” That project, called Cactus Trails, involved the county purchasing land for $1 an acre from the federal Bureau of Land Management.
“It’s not out of sight that we can do 500, 600 a year,” she said of the potential to scale up. Reaching that would likely require some financial investment.
Beyond the land, which the county already owned, the Rebecca Place homes may be subsidized by the county. If the cost to develop a CLT home is $370,000 but the attainable price is $320,000, the buyer’s mortgage would cover the latter amount and the county would cover the difference through a second silent mortgage.
The county will also offer downpayment assistance to help residents with upfront costs.
Kirkpatrick argues it’s a small investment considering what the county pays in rental assistance and other housing initiatives.
“I hope that we can move to where there’s no subsidies, except maybe for the permits and land, but today I’m prepared, I think it’s a good use of our dollars,” she added.
“There are always a few people that say the government shouldn’t be in the business. Well, I’m in the business one way or another. Might as well try to give people an opportunity to own a home.”

name: Alabama Reflector
title: Alabama State Board of Education could vote on new textbooks in February
description: Members of the Alabama State Board of Education (ALSBOE) could see textbooks back on the agenda next month. During a work session on Thursday, Alabama State Schools Superintendent Eric Mackey said decisions on adopting new social studies and arts textbooks — delayed over questions from state board members — will be brought back to the […]
text:
Textbooks pictured a in the Gordon Persons Building in downtown Montgomery, Alabama on Monday, May 15, 2023. The Alabama State Board of Education could take a long-delayed vote on new arts and social studies textbooks at its meeting next month. (Todd Van Emst for Alabama Reflector)Members of the Alabama State Board of Education (ALSBOE) could see textbooks back on the agenda next month.
During a work session on Thursday, Alabama State Schools Superintendent Eric Mackey said decisions on adopting new social studies and arts textbooks — delayed over questions from state board members — will be brought back to the agenda for the February meeting.
“I know that’s on people’s minds. I’ve been asked this morning ‘when is that going to come back?’” Mackey said.
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Board members were originally supposed to vote on recommendations for social studies and arts education textbooks made by two separate committees —  one for social studies and one for arts — during the board’s  meeting last November.
The two committees, were appointed in April to review and rate textbooks. Those ratings were then sealed and given to the board in October.
The vote was delayed because of concerns raised by board members about the social studies textbooks recommended. Some board members raised questions about the short timeframe to review the textbooks, while some also expressed concerns the books might not reflect what they consider the values of Alabamians.
Mackey told board members during this month’s work session that he has created a new proposal that should be presented next month.
“I’m going to get with [Marie] Manning and [Kelley] Mooney next week and go through my proposal. If they say ‘you are absolutely crazy, go rewrite this’ then it might be March,” he said.
Mackey did not mention what his new proposal included, but did say there are “enough options” to present to the board in February with hopes to further the process.
If adopted, the textbooks would be available for the 2026-2027 school year.

name: Michigan Advance
title: Michigan court rules state’s mental health procurement plan violates law
description: A Michigan court has ruled that the state’s plan to overhaul its mental health service delivery system violates state law, citing conflicts with the Michigan Mental Health Code.  The decision, issued Thursday by Judge Christopher P. Yates of the Michigan Court of Claims, declared that the state’s 2025 request for proposal for a competitive procurement […]
text:
Mental health advocates came out in opposition to a proposal from the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services they argue would privatize management of public mental health services during a rally at the state capitol. Sept. 17, 2025 | Photo by Kyle Davidson/Michigan AdvanceA Michigan court has ruled that the state’s plan to overhaul its mental health service delivery system violates state law, citing conflicts with the Michigan Mental Health Code. 
The decision, issued Thursday by Judge Christopher P. Yates of the Michigan Court of Claims, declared that the state’s 2025 request for proposal for a competitive procurement system restricts Community Mental Health Service Programs, which serve as the state’s prepaid inpatient mental health plan providers, from fulfilling their statutory obligations.
While the court denied the state’s motion to dismiss the lawsuit, it stopped short of issuing an injunction to halt the transition process, instead ordering the state to address the legal conflicts identified in the ruling and bring the proposal into compliance with Michigan law. The court emphasized that sufficient Medicaid funds must be allocated to providers to allow them to perform their statutory duties.
The case stems from lawsuits filed by multiple inpatient providers and counties against the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Technology, Management, and Budget. The plaintiffs argued that the proposal, which aims to transition to a competitive procurement system by reducing from 10 to three the number of regions that prepaid inpatient health plans operate in, would impair their ability to provide mandated mental health services.
The proposal involves up to $6 billion in state-administered funding and is set to take effect in October 2026. 
In his ruling, Yates stated that the proposal would stop inpatient mental health plan providers from making contracts with service providers, even though those contracts are necessary to pay for services and to manage mental health care properly.
As those providers are required by law to offer many essential services, including crisis care, screening before hospital admission, protecting patients’ rights, and mental health advocacy, Yates ruled that the proposal conflicts with Michigan law, which requires community mental health agencies to coordinate care and protect patients’ rights by working through contracts with service providers.
Thursday’s ruling is not final and does not resolve all pending claims in the case, with Yates indicating that the court would consider injunctive relief if the state fails to address the legal issues raised in the ruling.
